case_name: Civil Appeal No. 743 of 1963, Civil Appeals Nos. 553 and 554 of 1962

facts.text: Appellants in Civil Appeal No. 743 of 1963 are owners of lands in village Virk Kalan, Tehsil and District Bhatinda.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in Civil Appeal No. 743 of 1963 are owners of lands in village Virk Kalan, Tehsil and District Bhatinda.

facts.text: Appellants in Civil Appeals No. 553 and 554 of 1962 are owners of lands in villages Sewana and Mehnd of Tehsil Hansi in District Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in the other appeals are owners of lands in villages Sewana and Mehnd of Tehsil Hansi in District Hissar.

facts.text: Proceedings for consolidation of holdings are going on in these villages under the East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Proceedings for the consolidation of holdings are going on in these villages under the East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act 1948 (Act 50 of 1948).

facts.text: In village Virk Kalan 270 kanals and 13 marlas have been given to the village Panchayat for management and realisation of income, although ownership still shown as Shamlat Deh in names of proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: in village Virk Kalan 270 kanals and 13 marlas have been given to the village Panchayat for management and realisation of income, although the ownership is still shown in village papers as Shamlat Deh in the names of the proprietors

facts.text: In village Virk Kalan 10 kanals and 3 marlas reserved for abadi to be distributed among persons entitled thereto.

anchor.surface_text: and 10 kanals and 3 marlas have been reserved for abadi to be distributed among persons entitled thereto

facts.text: In village Virk Kalan 3 kanals and 7 marlas reserved for manure pits.

anchor.surface_text: and 3 kanals and 7 marlas have been reserved for manure pits.

facts.text: In village Sewana 400 kanals and 4 marlas set apart for village Panchayat for extension of abadi and grants of 8 marlas to each family of non-proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in village Sewana 400 kanals and 4 marlas have been set apart for the village Panchayat for extension of the abadi and to enable grants of 8 marlas of land to be made to each family of non-proprietors

facts.text: In village Sewana 16 kanals reserved for primary school and some more for phirni.

anchor.surface_text: and 16 kanals have been reserved for a primary school and some more for a phirni.

facts.text: In village Mehnd land reserved for village Panchayat, school, tanning ground, hospital, cremation ground and non-proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in village Mehnd, land has been reserved for the village Panchayat, a school, tanning ground, hospital, cremation ground and for non-proprietors.

facts.text: Proprietors were not paid compensation for the lands reserved.

anchor.surface_text: The proprietors were not paid compensation for the lands and it is the taking away and allotment of these lands which are the subject of challenge in these appeals

facts.text: East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act 1948 amended by East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation 2nd Amendment Validation Act 27 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: This Act was amended on many occasions but we are concerned with it as amended by the East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation 2nd Amendment Validation Act 27 of 1960.

facts.text: Rule 16 added by Punjab Government notification on March 3, 1956 for reservation of abadi for proprietors and non-proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1956 the Punjab Government, by a notification, added rule 16 to the Rules for reservation of the abadi for the proprietors as well as the non-proprietors

facts.text: Rule 16(ii) added on April 9, 1957 for reservation of lands for Gram Panchayat.

anchor.surface_text: On April 9, 1957 the Punjab Government added rule 16(ii) which provided for reservation of lands for the Gram Panchayat.

facts.text: Punjab High Court declared Rule 16(ii) ultra vires on November 5, 1959 in Munsha Singh v. State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16(ii) was declared ultra vires on November 5, 1959 by the Punjab High Court in Munsha Singh v. State of Punjab.

facts.text: Appellants filed Civil Writ Petition No. 319 of 1961 contending distribution of shamlat lands illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in this appeal had filed a Civil Writ Petition No. 319 of 1961 contending that the distribution of shamlat lands was illegal

facts.text: Grover J. dismissed writ petition No. 319 of 1961 on authority of Jagat Singh v. Punjab State.

anchor.surface_text: Grover J., who heard the petition, dismissed it on the authority of Jagat Singh v. Punjab State.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave against Grover J.'s order.

anchor.surface_text: Against his order special leave was granted by this Court

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 761 of 1957 dismissed by Grover J., Letters Patent Appeal filed.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 761 of 1957 (Civil Appeal No. 553 of 1962) was dismissed by Grover J. against whose decision a Letters Patent Appeal was filed.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed writ petitions and Letters Patent Appeal on August 18, 1960? Wait, September 12,1960 for some.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated December 13, 1961, and September 12, 1960 of the Punjab High Court

facts.text: These appeals challenge validity of Amending Act 27 of 1960, Rules 16(i) and (ii), and Common Lands Regulation Act.

anchor.surface_text: they challenge the correctness of the decision in Jagat Singh's case and thus question the validity of the Amending Act 27 of 1960 because they contend it is in breach of Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31 of the Constitution. Rules 16(i) and (ii) are also challenged.
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated December 13, 1961, and September 12, 1960 of the Punjab High Court
in C.W. No. 319 of 1961 and Civil Writ No. 454 of 1958 and Letters Patent No. 388 of 1958 respectively.

holdings.text: The transfer of shamlat deh owned by the proprietors to the village Panchayat for the purposes of management and the conferment of proprietary rights on non-proprietors in respect of lands in abadi deh is not illegal and the several provisions of law allowing this to be done are not ultra vires Art. 31 as no compensation is payable because the law and the action taken are protected by Art. 31-A.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Impugned actions part of agrarian reform scheme including rural planning and panchayat management; protected by broad interpretation of Art. 31A despite no compensation.

holdings.text: The impugned provisions come within the exception of agrarian reforms under Art. 31-A.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned provisions come within the exception of agrarian reforms but conflicting views were expressed regarding the ambit of Art. 31-A

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of precedents shows liberal interpretation of Art. 31A terms like estate and rights therein; includes consolidation, rural development, panchayat assignments.

holdings.text: K.K. Kochuni v. State of Madras is not applicable to these facts.

anchor.surface_text: But that was a special case and we cannot apply it to cases where the general scheme of legislation is definitely agrarian reform and under its provisions something ancillary thereto

holdings.reasoning_summary: Kochuni involved bare transfer without agrarian reform; here general scheme is agrarian reform with ancillary rural economy measures.

holdings.text: The proposed changes in the shamlat deh and abadi deh were included in the general scheme of planning of rural areas and the productive utilisation of vacant and waste lands.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was also right in its view that the proposed changes in the shamlat deh and abadi deh were included in the general scheme of planning of rural areas

holdings.reasoning_summary: Part of rural development envisaging equitable land distribution, economic standards, health; essential for reform success.

holdings.text: Assignment of lands to village Panchayat for community use including hospitals, schools, manure pits etc. is an essential part of agrarian reforms.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchayat best suited for rural welfare; protected under Art. 31A as authority under Part III.

holdings.text: The settling of agricultural artisans in abadi deh is a part of rural planning and comprehended in a scheme of agrarian reforms.

anchor.surface_text: With respect to abadi deh the same reasoning must apply The settling of a body of agricultural artisans such as the village carpenter, the village blacksmith, the village tanner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Makes villages self-sufficient; part of larger reforms like consolidation, ceilings, surplus distribution.

holdings.text: The four Acts (Consolidation Act, Village Panchayat Act, Common Lands Regulation Act, Security of Tenure Act) are a part of a general scheme of reforms protected by Art. 31-A.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Integrated scheme for agrarian reform; modifications of rights protected.

holdings.text: Act 27 of 1960 gives retrospective validity to Rules 16(i) and (ii), overruling Munsha Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in Jagat Singhs case has held that Act 27 of 1960 gives retrospective validity to rules 16 i and ii

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit retrospective amendments; High Court view accepted as position now obtains.

holdings.text: Common Lands Regulation Act valid and part of the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: They further challenge the Common Lands Regulation Act which is a part of the entire scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld previously; vesting in panchayat protected by Art. 31A as agrarian reform.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion these appeals must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges rejected; High Court correct on all points.

precedents.citation: Munsha Singh v. State of Punjab 1 ... I.L.R. 1960 1 Punjab 589

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16 ii  was declared ultra vires on November 5, 1959 by the Punjab High Court in Munsha Singh v. State of Punjab 1 . After Munsha Singhs case the second amending Act  27 of 1960  was passed. It gave legal cover to rule 16 ii  by including in section 2 of the Consolidation Act  50 of 1948  the following 2 bb  Common purpose means any purpose in relation to any common need, convenience or benefit of the village and includes the following purposes extension of the village abadi provide income for the Panchayat of the village concerned for the benefit of the village community-. village roads and paths village drains village wells, ponds or tanks village watercourses or water channels village bus stands and waiting places manure pits hada rori public latrines cremation and burial grounds Panchayat Ghar Janj Ghar grazing grounds tanning places mela grounds public places, of religious or charitable nature and schools and playgrounds, dispensaries, hospitals and institutions of like nature, water-works or tub---wells, whether such schools, play grounds  dispensaries, hospitals, institutions, water-works or tube- wells may be managed and controlled by the State Government or not.

precedents.case_name: Munsha Singh v State of Punjab

precedents.citation: Hukam Singh v. State of Punjab 1 ... I.L.R. 1955 Punjab 1334

anchor.surface_text: The Common Lands Regulation Act was challenged in Hukam Singh v. State of Punjab 1  but was upheld. The High Court, however, observed that Art. 31 2  would have rendered the Act void but for the enactment of Art. 31-A.

precedents.case_name: Hukam Singh v State of Punjab

precedents.citation: Atma Ram v. State of Punjab 2 ... 1959 S.C.R. 1 Supp. 748

anchor.surface_text: The validity of these Acts was challenged but they were upheld in Atma Ram v. State of Punjab 2  to which we shall refer later.

precedents.case_name: Atma Ram v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act upheld as agrarian reform

precedents.citation: Jagat Singh v. Punjab State 3 ... 1962 64 P.L.R. 241

anchor.surface_text: Grover J., who heard the petition ,dismissed it on the authority of Jagat Singh v. Punjab State 3 . Against his order special leave was granted by this Court and Civil Appeal No. 743 of 1963 is the result.

precedents.cited_proposition: Act 27 of 1960 valid and saved by Art. 31A

precedents.citation: K. K. Kochuni v. State of Madras 3 ... 1960 3 S.C.R. 887

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has also decided that Act 27 of 1960 is saved by Art. 31-A and the case of this Court in K. K. Kochuni v. State of Madras 3  which interpreted Art. 31-A, as amended by the Constitution  Fourth Amendment  Act, 1955, is not applicable.

precedents.case_name: K K Kochuni v State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 31A protects only agrarian reforms, not bare transfers of property
precedents.cited_holding: Madras Marumakkathayam Removal of Doubts Act invalid under Art. 19(1)(f) and not saved by Art. 31A

anchor.surface_text: The observations of this Court in Thakur Raghubir Singhs case 1  were explained and were confined to the facts of that case.

precedents.case_name: Thakur Raghubir Singh v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Early interpretation of Art. 31A terms given wide connotation

precedents.citation: Gangadhar Narayanrao Majumdar State of Bombay 3 ... 1961 1 S.C.R. 943

anchor.surface_text: In Gangadhar Narayanrao Majumdar State of Bombay 3  in considering the words estate and rights in an estate, the right of an inamdar under Bombay Acts Nos. 11, VII of 1863 to appropriate to himself the difference between the full assessment and the quit rent was treated as a right in an estate and its extinguishment, or modification, was considered to protected by Art. 31-A.

precedents.case_name: Gangadhar Narayanrao Majumdar v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Inamdar's right is a right in an estate protected by Art. 31A

precedents.citation: Ram Narain Medhi v. State of Bombay 4 ... 1959 Supp. 1.S.C.R. 489

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in Ram Narain Medhi v. State of Bombay 4  the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands  Amendment  Act 1956  which amended Bombay Act LXVII of 1948  was in question.

precedents.case_name: Ram Narain Medhi v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Land redistribution to prevent concentration protected by Art. 31A

precedents.citation: Sonapur Tea Co. Ltd. v. Must. Mazirunnessa 2 ... 1962 1 S.C.R. 724

anchor.surface_text: in Sonapur Tea Co. Ltd. v. Must. Mazirunnessa 2  the validity of the Assam Fixation of Ceiling of Land Holdings Act, 1957 was considered and the question was whether the rights which were taken away or abridged by the Assam Act were rights in relation to an estate within the meaning of Art. 3 1 -A  2   b  of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Sonapur Tea Co Ltd v Mst Mazirunnessa
precedents.cited_proposition: Ceiling rights extinguished are rights in relation to an estate under Art. 31A

precedents.citation: Burrakur Coal Co. Ltd. v. Union of India 4 ... 1962 2 S.C.R. 382

anchor.surface_text: The same conclusion regarding the meaning of the word modification was reached in Burrakur Coal Co. Ltd. v. Union of India 4  without adverting to Kochuni case 5 .

precedents.case_name: Burrakur Coal Co Ltd v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Modification of rights protected by Art. 31A

precedents.citation: State of Bihar v. Rameshwar Pratap Narain Singh 6

anchor.surface_text: See also State of Bihar v. Rameshwar Pratap Narain Singh 6  and state of Bihar v. Umesh Jha 5 .

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v Rameshwar Pratap Narain Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Rights under land reforms protected by Art. 31A

precedents.citation: state of Bihar v. Umesh Jha 5 ... 1962 2 S.C.R. 687

anchor.surface_text: See also State of Bihar v. Rameshwar Pratap Narain Singh 6  and state of Bihar v. Umesh Jha 5 . In the latter a provision of the Bihar Land Reforms Act 1950, as amended by the Bihar Land reforms  Amendment  Act, 1959 which empowered the Collector to annual anticipatory transfers of land designed to defeat the object of the Act was held to be protected by Art. 31-A, though the section by itself did not provide for the extinguishment or Modification of any rights in an estate.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v Umesh Jha
precedents.cited_proposition: Ancillary provisions in land reform acts protected by Art. 31A
